newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turkish shares edge up 0.16 pct to new record.
newsitem.headline: Turkish shares edge up 0.16 pct to new record.

text.p: Istanbul shares firmed slightly in highly selective activity on Thursday despite profit-taking which erased most of the early morning gains, brokers said.
The IMKB-100 closed 146.74 points, or 0.16 percent higher at a new all-time high of 94,451.17, compared to a previous high of 94,407.21 on December 6. It fell from an early high of 96,480.
In dollar terms, the index stood at $0.89, down from $0.92 on December 6 and a $1 record on April 8.
Trade volume jumped to 31.19 trillion lira ($294.8 million) from Wednesday's 25.15 trillion ($238.3 million) with the help of fresh cash influx.

"The market may revive the old index target of one dollar. Such profit-taking waves are normal. Strong volume confirms the current rise and the index may exceed 95,000 if activity spills over to the whole market," said Nazmi Sarikaya from Disbank.
The index had lost 5.37 percent last week amid rumours ahead of the S&P's rating cut and negative sentiment after a failed attempt to overcome stiff resistance at 95,000.
Three-day gains totalled 8.37 percent since Monday's 2.44 percent fall prompted by the S&P's dowgrading of Turkey's long-term foreign currency debt rating last Friday.
